content.webTitle: Indigenous children embark on epic ride to honour war veterans and Light Horse Infantry

fields.headline: Indigenous children embark on epic ride to honour war veterans and Light Horse Infantry
fields.bodyText: A remote central Australian community has waved off a group of schoolchildren who are embarking on a five-day horse ride to the Alice Springs Anzac Day parade to honour Indigenous soldiers. The 36 students, from the community of Ntaria, or Hermannsburg, set off on the Arrarnta Tribe Ride For Pride on Wednesday morning, after a blessing and farewell from the community. In five days they will cross 127km of desert on wild brumbies they helped train and arrive in Alice Springs in time to take part in the desert town’s Anzac Day parade. On foot and on horseback the students will march to honour and remember Indigenous war veterans and the central desert brumbies used by the Light Horse Infantry in the first world war. Because of the close proximity of Easter to Anzac Day this year, the normally six-day journey has been packed into five. A support crew of non-riding students will learn and work with Indigenous rangers along the way. Jeremy Moketarinja, an assistant teacher with the school who also teaches the students to ride, is accompanying his daughter on the journey. “I love horses, I like training with Chris and seeing all these kids riding horses, going through bushes and all that stuff, sleeping under the stars and sitting around the campfire telling stories,” he says. “All the Aboriginal people from here went to fight wars somewhere in Turkey for the light horsemen. That’s why we’re doing it for them and for ourselves and our community. To make every blackfella in Australia happy because there’s nothing like this happening in other schools.” Moketarinja said it was “good fun” to work with the children and he was proud to see them take part in the ride. “You see what you learned them. Some of these kids had never ridden a horse before. My daughter is with us, she’d never rode any horse before and she’s doing good now.” The trip is the highlight of the Ntaria school’s horse training program, a VET course open to senior students from year 9 to 12 in the hopes it will raise attendance and school engagement. Since 2013 students have learned to train and ride wild brumbies while gaining certification in agriculture, rural operations, or tourism. “This year especially we’re really starting to see the fruits of our labour,” Chris Barr, a teacher and the horse trainer at the school, tells Guardian Australia. “Self-confidence is going through the roof – their self-confidence and their attitude towards coming to school.” Barr says the school has seen 90% attendance among the children enrolled in the horse program in the past year. It’s difficult to overstate the horse culture in Ntaria, rivalled in popularity only by AFL. Wild brumbies can often be seen running through the surrounding country, made famous by the watercolour artist Albert Namatjira. Days-long rides and events are regular features on the calendar and horses feature in much of the local artworks. The course is open to all senior students from year 9 to year 12 and has seen an increase in numbers on last year. “This program is so important for our students, it brings the whole community together and celebrates our Indigenous servicemen past and present,” Ntaria school principal Cath Greene said. “Our students are here in droves every day; this program gives them something to look forward to and teaches them far more than the competencies can evaluate.”
